senses.de: To cause strong feelings of enthusiasm and eagerness in (someone)
senses.ex: The new movie trailer excited the fans to a great degree.

Tips.title: Positive Emotions
Tips.description: Used to express joy or anticipation; associated with happy excitement.
Tips.example: She was excited about her birthday party.

Tips.title: Not Always Positive
Tips.description: 'Excite' can also imply nervousness or anxiety in anticipation.
Tips.example: He's excited but also nervous about the job interview.

Tips.title: Intensity Matters
Tips.description: Can indicate varying levels of interest, from mild to intense eagerness.
Tips.example: The idea of traveling excites me.

senses.de: To arouse or bring out (e.g. a reaction or emotion)
senses.ex: Spicy food can excite the sense of taste.

Tips.title: Triggering Reaction
Tips.description: Refers to causing someone to react, often unexpectedly or strongly.
Tips.example: His harsh words excited a fierce debate.

Tips.title: Subtle Provocation
Tips.description: May imply a more delicate or intellectual stimulation.
Tips.example: Art has the power to excite the imagination.

senses.ex: The protestors excited the crowd with their powerful speeches.

Tips.title: Stimulate Action
Tips.description: Often describes instigation or encouragement of activities, sometimes disruptive.
Tips.example: Their words excited the audience to take action.

Tips.title: Negative Context
Tips.description: Can have a negative connotation, suggesting agitation or trouble.
Tips.example: The rumors excited suspicion among the employees.

senses.de: To cause a particular reaction in an organ or cell of the body or in any of its constituents
senses.ex: Certain drugs can excite the central nervous system.

Tips.title: Technical Usage
Tips.description: In medical or scientific contexts, it means to stimulate on a biological level.
Tips.example: Bright lights can excite the photoreceptors in the eye.

Tips.title: Precise Activation
Tips.description: Refers to a specific and targeted triggering of a response in science.
Tips.example: The drug can excite certain enzymes.

Agitate.wordDefinition:
Agitate means to stir up or disturb, often causing feelings of unease or unrest.

For example, if a political group is trying to agitate the public in order to provoke a protest, they may use inflammatory language or images.

Animate.wordDefinition:
Animate means to give life or energy to something that is not alive, like a cartoon character or a puppet. It is applicable when we want to bring something to life or make it more lively.

For example, we can say, "The animator animated the character to make it more fun to watch."

Arouse.wordDefinition:
The words arouse and excite both mean to stimulate or activate feelings, but arouse usually refers to sexual feelings whereas excite can refer to any strong emotion (e.g.

For example, you may hear someone say "the music really aroused me" when they mean they found the music sexually stimulating.

Overall, both words can be applicable in many different situations depending on the context, but arouse is primarily used in a sexual context whereas excite can refer to any strong emotion.

Inspire.wordDefinition:
Both excite and inspire convey enthusiasm and motivation, but there is a subtle difference between the two. Excite refers to creating a feeling of excitement, interest, or eagerness in someone, while inspire means to encourage or stimulate someone to do something creative or great.

For example, a thrilling rollercoaster ride might excite you, while a motivational speech from an accomplished individual might inspire you to pursue your dreams.

Excite is more suitable for situations that evoke emotions, while inspire is better used in situations that encourage action or creative pursuits.

Motivate.wordDefinition:
Excite means to cause feelings of enthusiasm or eagerness, whereas the word motivate means to provide a reason or incentive to do something.

If someone motivates you to study for a test, they are giving you a reason or incentive to work hard and achieve good results.

Excite describes feelings of enthusiasm, while motivate describes the reasons why someone is doing something or the incentives that are driving them forward.

Rouse.wordDefinition:
Both excite and rouse mean to stimulate or arouse someone's feelings or emotions.

However, excite refers to creating a feeling of enthusiasm, eagerness or anticipation, whereas rouse implies awakening someone, typically from a state of sleep or inactivity, and bringing them into an alert and active state.

For example, you might be excited about a new movie coming out, but you would rouse your friend out of bed to go see it with you.

Another example is, a motivational speaker might excite the audience with their speech, while the sound of a fire alarm would rouse people from a deep sleep.

Stimulate.wordDefinition:
Excite and stimulate are both words that describe the act of making someone feel more energized or interested in something.

Stimulate is used when referring to the act of triggering a physical or mental response to something. For example, coffee is known to stimulate the brain and make people feel more alert.

Stimulating things usually make people feel more focused or awake.

In summary, exciting things make people feel enthusiastic or emotionally charged, while stimulating things improve focus or alertness.

Thrill.wordDefinition:
Thrill means to cause someone to feel an intense rush of excitement or pleasure.

It is typically used to describe something that is particularly exciting or exhilarating. For example, going on a roller coaster might thrill someone, or seeing their team win the championship might thrill them.

Both words are applicable in different situations, but thrill is generally reserved for more intense experiences, while excite can be used for a broader range of experiences.

quotes.Text: Acting is always at the core of my life, but I'm also excited about producing. I'm excited about directing, and I have a life in the filmmaking world, and so I want to explore all aspects of it, not just the acting, but acting is the root.
quotes.Title: Actor
quotes.Name: Nicolas Cage

quotes.Text: Football's the biggest game in the world. America's the greatest sporting nation there is. To play some part in putting those two things together: why wouldn't I be excited about that?
quotes.Title: English Footballer
quotes.Name: David Beckham

quotes.Text: Every time I come to Europe, I'm just as excited as I was my very first time, which was many, many years ago. I love that part of the world, and I especially love the fans.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Dolly Parton

quotes.Text: I'm always excited to carry more and more weight and responsibility within a story.
quotes.Title: Canadian Actor
quotes.Name: Kevin Durand

quotes.Text: Passion is energy. Feel the power that comes from focusing on what excites you.
quotes.Title: American Entertainer
quotes.Name: Oprah Winfrey

quotes.Text: When I joined 'Kumkum,' I was excited because the character had grey shades.

quotes.Name: Hiten Tejwani

quotes.Text: I don't get bored of life. I always find things that excite me.
quotes.Title: Indian Actress
quotes.Name: Suhasini Maniratnam

quotes.Text: I am very excited about the future and very motivated also.

quotes.Name: Paulo Gazzaniga

quotes.Text: Good writing excites me, and makes life worth living.
quotes.Title: English Dramatist
quotes.Name: Harold Pinter

quotes.Text: We are so excited about life and about every song.

quotes.Name: Tucker Halpern
